review_title: Jobs are fascinating and like no other but organisation can be frustrating
pros:
- Making a real difference to the lives of the people we support 

- The NAS is very good at campaigning and creating awareness of autism (they were instrumental in the Autism Act 2012 being passed) and this helps

- Great colleagues, most of whom are passionate about the work 

- Good training opportunities

- Reasonable holiday provision and sickness benefit etc (though the latter has recently been reduced)
cons:
- Rewards for staff are poor, very low pay (and not even inflationary rises for many years) and a feeling that the organisation itself doesn't appreciate you. On the same point, funding cuts make the job much harder and impacts negatively on the people we support (as does the relatively high staff turnover). Much of this is down to the level of finding local councils are willing or able to provide, but the NAS should be campaigning for its staff, telling the government how difficult it is to provide proper support for some of the most vulnerable people in society on the money they receive and how difficult it is for their staff to live on such low wages

- Senior management are remote and the concerns of the average employee seem lost to the wind. There is an 'us and them' feeling which need not exist

- Communication should be improved

review_title: The founding members of the NAS would be rolling in their graves if they knew this.
pros:
Some good services, and some good staff, but many of the good staff just get frustrated and leave.

If you’re a psychopath, or at least lack morals and can master office politics, you’ll do well and enjoy it.
cons:
Forget meritocracy here.  Office politics is all.  I spent years not being promoted, despite every single other person doing a similar role for at least two years whilst I was there being promoted despite most of them being less able and qualified – inevitably, there were ‘business needs’ for every single one of their promotions.  Why promote or give a payrise to someone who is likely to stay anyway as autistic people find change and gaining alternative employment much more difficult?  Furthermore, I was once promised a payrise only a few days before it being denied this was ever said.

Forget the social model of disability or the double empathy theory here.  If you’re an autistic person, you’ll be expected to fit in with the neurotypical majority, or suffer.

Forget any understanding that autistic people will take longer to get used to change – here, it’ll be judged at face value, and you’ll be considered a slow learner.  
Furthermore, that assumption won’t be revisited as first impressions are all that count – instead, you’ll be taunted and deliberately misunderstood to depress and frustrate you even more, and the effects of that on your mental health will also be taken at face value and used against you.

If you value your mental health, don’t work here unless you’re a psychopath, or at least lack morals and can master office politics.  I ended up off sick due to stress and depression caused by the above -- I was also too worn down to continue suffering in silence.  There was some token support, but look and behold, within months 'business reasons' were found to make me redundant -- how convenient?

The founding members of the NAS would be rolling in their graves if they knew what was happening to autistic employees in their charity.
